Stop checking email. Start processing it.

11 Mar 2013

Email is an avalanche that never stops coming. And the problem will only get worse. Inboxes will get fuller. More people will be able to send more email from more devices.

One could argue that email’s benefits are being eroded.

Indeed, people have been seeking the holy grail of “inbox zero” since 2006.

If the deluge isn’t going to stop, something else has to change. And that something else has to be our relationship with email. We’re going to have to put it back in it’s place.

Sounds hard, right? Well a new app I’ve been using is helping. Mailbox seems to be working because it addresses habit change, not just email.

Mailbox’s premise is:

  • You should control email, not the other way around.
  • Your inbox is for new information; It’s not a to-do list, and it’s not an archive.

The shift I’m making is from ‘checking’ my email to ‘processing’ it.

I find I’m more inclined to schedule ‘processing’ email as an activity, where I answer, delete, delegate, ask for it to come back later or file my emails in lists.

If you really need help trying to stop checking email, try implementing this: http://inboxpause.com/

And if you could use some amazingly cogent tips on curbing your email habit, try Mike Rooney’s post on achieving email bliss.
